title: 111_hr4343
content:
The "Minority Business Development Improvements Act of 2009" establishes the Minority Business Development Program to assist qualified minority businesses with technical assistance, loan guarantees, and contract procurement assistance. The Director may certify entities as qualified minority businesses if they meet specific criteria: at least 51% ownership by historically disadvantaged individuals, key officers are historically disadvantaged individuals, principals' net worth not exceeding $2,000,000, US-based operations, and good character maintained by principals. Entities seeking certification as qualified minority businesses must engage in competitive commercial operations in a specific industry sector with a North American Industry Classification System code. They must also submit reports to the Director as required and meet any additional criteria determined by the Director. Certification is valid for 5 years and cannot be renewed. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE.

The Director may provide technical assistance to qualified minority businesses for writing business plans, marketing, management, and securing financing. Agreements can be made for this assistance, and $200,000,000 is authorized for this purpose.

SEC. 5. LOAN GUARANTEES. The Director may guarantee up to 90 percent of a loan for qualified minority businesses for various business purposes, such as purchasing equipment, payroll expenses, and facilities. The guarantees are made on terms determined by the Director, ensuring a reasonable prospect of repayment by the borrower. The Director may guarantee a loan for qualified minority businesses for various purposes. If a borrower defaults on the obligation, the guarantee holder can demand payment from the Director. The Director must pay the unpaid amount within a specified period. If the borrower defaults, the Director may find no default in payment or remedy the default. Forbearance is allowed if agreed upon by both parties. The Director is subrogated to the recipient's rights if a payment is made. The Director has the authority to complete, maintain, operate, lease, or dispose of property acquired through the guarantee. The borrower may continue pursuing project purposes if deemed in the public interest by the Director. The Director's rights regarding property acquired through a guarantee are superior to others. The guarantee agreement includes terms to protect US interests in case of default and ensure access to necessary patents and technology. The Director may pay principal and interest on guaranteed obligations if the borrower is unable to meet payments and it is in the public interest to continue. The Director may pay principal and interest on guaranteed obligations to allow the borrower to pursue project purposes, with the condition that the reimbursement will be greater than the default outcome. The payment amount cannot exceed the borrower's obligation under the agreement. The Director may pay principal and interest on guaranteed obligations to enable the borrower to pursue project purposes, with reimbursement conditions. In case of default, the Director notifies the Attorney General for recovery actions. Fees for guarantees collected by the Director shall cover administrative expenses, not exceeding 1 percent of the guaranteed amount. Fees are deposited into the Treasury and remain available for expenditure. Minority businesses must meet credit requirements to receive a guaranteed loan. The Director may guarantee up to $450,000 of any loan and a loan cannot exceed $500,000. $500,000,000 is authorized for appropriations to carry out this section from 2011 to 2016. SEC. 6. SET-ASIDE CONTRACTING OPPORTUNITIES. The Director may enter agreements with the US Government for procurement contracts to benefit qualified minority businesses. Participation rules and annual contract limits are set, with a maximum contract amount of $6,000,000 for goods and services. The Director may enter agreements with the US Government for procurement contracts to benefit qualified minority businesses. Contracts for manufacturing and construction services under this section may not exceed $10,000,000. SEC. 7. TERMINATION FROM THE PROGRAM.

The Director may terminate a qualified minority business from the Program for violations including lack of business integrity, failure to comply with labor standards, inadequate contract performance, lack of certifications, and unpaid obligations to the Federal Government. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

The Director must submit an annual report to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce and the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation detailing Program activities. The Secretary of Commerce must also submit an annual report to the same committees outlining efforts to promote wealth among historically disadvantaged individuals.

SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "historically disadvantaged individual" refers to a person eligible for assistance under specific regulations, and "principal" is someone with significant control over a business entity's operations.
